item.title: Let there be light!
item.description: Needing an outdoor light by our front door, but - despite being an electronics engineer and weirdly averse to, and fearful of 240V mains electricity - I decided to create a custom battery powered Passive-Infrared (PIR) sensor and LED light. This avoided the need for drilling holes from inside to outside, and adding a stub from the indoor lighting mains ring. I had a few old car and motorbike batteries spare.

item.title: My DataScience Capstone Project Submission
item.description: I recently completed the Coursera / Johns Hopkins University “Data Science Specialization”, a series of ten courses culminating in a Capstone project in which we students had to develop a text-prediction application. This was to be demonstrated in a Shiny App. Below is my “promotional slide deck” for this text-prediction application. Shiny is a powerful framework for deploying interactive R web apps, but I’m still a bit of a noob when it come’s to creating a polished app - to be worked upon!

item.title: R Markdown in Hugo using Blogdown
item.description: R Markdown Throughout my ongoing journey of discovery and learning instatistics and data science , my mainstay computing environment has been the R Studio IDE. I found initially that it is quite hard to include R markdown output in blogging sites like Wordpress. This led me to create my own website from scratch (in simple HTML,CSS and Javascript) but this rapidly become cumbersome to maintain, even as a static site.

item.title: Am I being interfered with?
The Mode in R
item.description: When I first started learning R early in 2020, it cames as a bit of a suprise that there were functions in base R for calculating the mean and median, but not the mode. Well, there is a function mode(), but it returns the storage mode of an R object! Of course, the mean only operates on numeric data, as does the R median() function. But we could take the mode of a collection of pretty much any objects, numeric, factor, or otherwise.

item.title: Bibliography
item.description: It may be a bit square to refer to keep a library of books in this day and age, but I find books to be reassuringly apocalypse-resistant repositories of knowledge, often with far clearer and more understandable explanations than you’ll find on most statistics and data science web pages. Here’s a small sample of my statistics books: “Applied Statistics: Principles and Examples” by D.R.Cox and E.J.Snell (Chapman & Hall, 1981) “Problem Solving: A Statistician’s Guide” by C.
